overview.title: Overview
bullets: Economic indicators are statistical measures that reveal the state of an economy—helping traders assess growth, inflation, employment and broader conditions.
Market reactions to these releases can be significant, moving prices across asset classes such as equities, bonds, currencies and commodities.
Knowing the key indicators helps traders anticipate moves and align strategies with macro trends.

items.gdp: Gross Domestic Product (GDP): Measures total economic output and is a primary gauge of economic health. Rising GDP signals growth; falling GDP indicates contraction.
items.cpi: Consumer Price Index (CPI): Tracks changes in the cost of a basket of goods and services—the primary measure of inflation. Hot CPI often prompts tighter policy.
items.employment: Employment Data: Includes unemployment rate and nonfarm payrolls, offering insight into labor-market conditions. Strong employment supports growth; weak data can signal slowdown.
items.retailSales: Retail Sales: A proxy for consumer spending, a major driver of growth. Higher sales suggest confidence; lower sales may hint at weakness.
items.ppi: Producer Price Index (PPI): Measures producer-level price changes and can foreshadow consumer inflation trends.
items.tradeBalance: Trade Balance: The gap between exports and imports that influences currency strength—surpluses support, deficits can weigh.

stocks.title: 1. Stock Markets
bullets: Positive data (e.g., rising GDP or strong jobs) can boost risk appetite and propel equity markets.
High inflation or slowing growth can pressure stocks as investors price tighter policy or a downturn.

bonds.title: 2. Bond Markets
bullets: Strong data can push yields higher (prices lower) as markets anticipate rate hikes or faster growth.
Weak data can pull yields lower (prices higher) as investors seek safety and central banks turn dovish.

fx.title: 3. Currency Markets (Forex)
bullets: Strong indicators (e.g., GDP or jobs) often support the currency via higher expected rates and capital inflows.
Weak data can weigh on the currency as lower rate expectations reduce attractiveness.

cmd.title: 4. Commodity Markets
bullets: Stronger growth signals can lift demand for commodities (e.g., oil, metals) and support prices.
Weaker data can dampen demand, softening commodity prices as production and consumption slow.

benefits.title: Benefits of Monitoring Economic Indicators
bullets: Anticipate Market Trends: Use macro conditions to contextualize and forecast potential price moves.
Inform Investment Decisions: Support asset allocation and portfolio adjustments with data-driven insights.
Gauge Economic Health: A clearer macro picture helps size risk and timing across the cycle.

limitations.title: Limitations of Relying on Economic Indicators
bullets: Lagging Nature: Some indicators (like GDP) reflect the past and may not capture current conditions.
Volatility Risk: Major releases can trigger sharp, unpredictable moves—especially in FX and equities.
Interpretation Complexity: Mixed signals are common; experience and corroborating data are essential.
